argumentText:
The claim is trivially true for $n=0, 1$.

By setting $x=y$ in the triangle inequality we have $\ell(x^2) \le 2\,\ell(x)$.
We use this as the base case for our induction and assume $\ell(x^k) \le k\,\ell(x).$

Then for $n=k+1$, 

$\ell(x^{k+1}) \le \ell(x^{k}) + \ell(x)$ using the triangle inequality on elements $x^k$ and $x$

Using this and our assumption we get $\ell(x^{k+1}) \le (k+1)\,\ell(x).$ This proves that $\ell(x^n) \le n\,\ell(x)$ for $n \ge 0$.

Since $\ell(x^{-n}) = \ell(x^n)$, we get $\ell(x^n) \le {- n}\,\ell(x)$ for $n < 0$.

We can combine the above two statements to get our claim.
